Posts.Content: Mand123 Well Mooninsmum, you have truly inspired me to give it another bash if u suffered and persevered I too can do this. You're prob right that in another 3 weeks I will be ready to try it again.  Thanks  Amanda X    Keep going lovely, you'll get there, if you want to ask any questions message me, is bloody hard but doable! Xx
Posts.Title: Sickness with cold cap

Posts.Content: Hi Amy, loads of fab advice here, love this site You may have 2 drains as have one for mx then one for the anc. My anc drain came out before I left hospital the breast one a week after... a book bag with long straps is handy to carry around and loop over arms of chairs etc.  I lived in leggings and vest tops (could pull the vest up over my torso then hook the straps over arms) if I got cold an oversized shirt was good. I only wore front fastening bras as couldn't put my arms behind to do up iyswim. I slept with 3 pillows so extras are good..  Was given gabapentin for the nerve pain/spasms (anc pain is worse than the mx pain but manageable) after which helped only used a couple of times but meant I could sleep (wish I had them now..  tamoxifen + hot flushes = no sleep!lol)  Do the exercises from the leaflet as soon as you can, the more movement you can do early the easier it feels.  Good luck hope it all goes well, remember to rest and look after yourself too xx
Posts.Title: Practical post mastectomy stuff

Posts.Content: Poor you Mand123, for me the worst part was the cold cap and feeling sick because of it. I get headaches really easily and have suffered with migraines so found the cap where it squished my head would cause my head to ache and then I'd feel nauseous, this lasted about 3 days after each session.  I can't really offer any advice, all I did was take paracetamol about an hour before then had some ibuprofen just as the cap was being put on.   Hopefully the sick feeling will fade, if not tell your oncology team, hopefully they can help? Maybe you need better anti sickness meds? (I had Emend which was good.  ) Good luck, I'm pleased I persevered as have a full head of hair (finished in January) now rather than just fluff, but there were times I nearly stopped,  see how you feel this time next week and then the week after you'll be surprised how you forget the bad when you feel a bit better xx
Posts.Title: Sickness with cold cap

Posts.Content: Mand123 Well Mooninsmum, you have truly inspired me to give it another bash if u suffered and persevered I too can do this. You're prob right that in another 3 weeks I will be ready to try it again.  Thanks  Amanda X    Keep going lovely, you'll get there, if you want to ask any questions message me, is bloody hard but doable! Xx
Posts.Title: Sickness with cold cap

Posts.Content: Poor you Mand123, for me the worst part was the cold cap and feeling sick because of it. I get headaches really easily and have suffered with migraines so found the cap where it squished my head would cause my head to ache and then I'd feel nauseous, this lasted about 3 days after each session.  I can't really offer any advice, all I did was take paracetamol about an hour before then had some ibuprofen just as the cap was being put on.   Hopefully the sick feeling will fade, if not tell your oncology team, hopefully they can help? Maybe you need better anti sickness meds? (I had Emend which was good.  ) Good luck, I'm pleased I persevered as have a full head of hair (finished in January) now rather than just fluff, but there were times I nearly stopped,  see how you feel this time next week and then the week after you'll be surprised how you forget the bad when you feel a bit better xx
Posts.Title: Sickness with cold cap

Posts.Content: Hi Kiwi,  Poor you sounds like you had a rough time post surgery, i had a lh mx with node clearance last August and like you the pins and needles pain/itch drove me nuts in exactly the same place, massaging the area helped but in the end was prescribed Gabapentin tablets which helped immensely (they also help with the night sweats/flushes you get with Tamoxifen!) I only took them for a few days post surgery but it was worth it.... It doesn't last forever, I think a month after i was still getting the odd tingle but no where near as many or as painful... Good luck!.. persevere with the exercises (as they are really good!) and after a good stretch and massage I felt much better... all the best Nix x
Posts.Title: Advice please-Mastectomy with lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: I empathise completely... I  cry at EVERYTHING now, there was a bullying video on Facebook yesterday ... bawled... my teen daughter's on a school trip hadn't heard from her till an hour ago she went yesterday morning... cried on and off and was awake most of the night worrying...  books, films and yes adverts get me all the time... I think it is a case of being unsettled, I don't think we ever relax after being diagnosed, I know i don't so nerves are jangling. There are hours when I don't think about cancer, then I remember still have surgery to go through and check ups to go to so feel it just hasn't stopped for me and you too I imagine (just counted it's 17 months for me... exhausting is definitely the word!) Hopefully London, your GP will be sympathetic and helpful, and if your BCN is naff ask for a different one! Just keep on moaning (I think it helps!)  take care, Nix xx
Posts.Title: Over Emotional....

Posts.Content: I found it quite candid and honest which surprised me after the last video which irritated me. Not sure how the videos will pan out after she's had 2 or 3, has bald patches and bags under her eyes but hope they'll still be truthful. I "breezed" through fec 1 but have found it harder and harder as I've gone on (fec 4 in 2 weeks), I'm cold capping and even watching that made me nauseous :( Good luck to her though, hope she gets through ok wouldn't wish the se's on anyone.
Posts.Title: Anybody else been Victoria Derbyshired????????

Posts.Content: SpicedTea, I feel your pain, my hair thinned loads in the first two and as I said I nearly gave up, make sure you have the correct sized inner hat (the gel bit) as I think that was my problem in the first two as it wasn't as tight as it should have been. It is depressing as you put all your hope in it working, go through all that pain and then feel it's let you down  The amount coming out feels like loads but it does slow down, maybe try one more and see how that one is, contact Paxman if you want a chat about it they're very helpful xx
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: You sound spookily like me Iona, I wore woolly hats everyday from September until a couple of weeks ago. I had mine cut short 3 weeks after the last chemo as my hair was long in parts and really short in others so it's short at the back now and longer at the front (have loads of bits sticking out at all angles as curly bet you will too lol). Is still curly and is thickening by the day. I wash it every day now and is a lovely feeling being able to rub hard with my fingers I really missed that. Our crowning glories will be back in no time you'll see! xx
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Hi, thought I'd add my five cents worth... I cold capped. Had 6 X fec 100 so was told would definitely lose my hair. In preparation I had it cut shorter about chin length, btw I had lots of hair, my hair's fine but curly.   I had the Paxman cooling system which was put on for 30 mins before chemo then had to stay on for 3.5 hours after treatment. Won't lie, was the worst bit of the chemo treatment for me and as the sessions went on it got harder as my hair thinned about 50-60%. Is an intense pain for about 15 mins they changes to a dull ache a bit like toothache. I Finished in January and now have a full head of hair ☺️. It's short (for me) and much thinner but the thin spots I had from where the cap didn't fit properly have all filled in. I've dyed it also so now just have short hair. I nearly gave up after chemo no.2 as loads came out and I felt sick thinking about having it again, but I persevered and am now so glad I did.  Tips - make sure the cap is snug to your head no air bubbles, only wash once or twice a week with very mild shampoo & conditioner. I used the Philip Kingsley no scent or colour it lasted throughout my treatment and as had no smell didn't make me feel ill by association (some money goes to a BC charity too). If using the Paxman system look at their website it's v.helpful and when I emailed about tips to get over the nausea by association and told them that the chinstrap was tight and dug in they rang me and sent me a larger chin strap for me to use and really encouraged me to keep going.  It's tough but doable, just like the chemo, good luck with whatever you decide xx
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Sorry I posted and didn't see your reply, go for it! See how you get on, no one will judge if you give up,  but it works so hopefully will for you..  Chemo wasn't as bad Looking back as I anticipated, the first one was hard as nothing to compare to, and no4 was hard as so near the end but not really.  Be kind to yourself, sleep when needed and eat and drink what you fancy, when you fancy, keep popping in here too as so very helpful to read that others are going through the same as you. Btw - I had my treatment on a Tuesday and by Sunday generally felt more human again, good luck xx
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Hi, Paxman sent me an xl chin strap which I took with me everytime, I still felt scrinched up but not so much, plus if you have your own you can add something soft to it so it doesn't hurt as much. I only washed my hair the morning after treatment and then 5 days later eg had treatment on a Tuesday washed on a weds (or Tuesday eve after I got home) then washed again, Sunday or Monday I patted the shampoo on never rubbed and sometimes only used conditioner, it looked pants but was still there so kept going, hats were my friend!  I have a flaky scalp too oils helped just before washing but found no perfume/no colour shampoos were the best for no build up or itchiness, keep going Nicky you'll get there xx
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Hi Paula,  I  cold capped... I don't get regular migraines but have had my fair share over the years, my head is very sensitive and I get a headache very easily that floor me and make me sick. Was put off initially because of this but I cold capped for my son really, he was 10 and was devastated about me having no hair and would get very upset talking about it, this swayed me I think to try it... I took some nurofen before I arrived at the hospital and had the cap fitted, it is very tight and causes a lot of downward pressure as has to be snug so all your scalp is covered... the initial cold sensation is very intense and painful, lasts about 15-20 mins then changes to a dull numbing ache is difficult to describe but I found that I couldn't really concentrate on a book so watched TV as could tune in and out. I had 6 x fec 100 so had to have the cap on for 30 mins before chemo then 3.5 hours after for it to work. After it comes off the relief is immense, and I did have a residual headache which lasted for a few days which may have been the chemo or the cap... it did put me off but by week 3 thought i'd try again .... so.. I persevered even after masses of hair fell out after the first one, (beanies were my friend!) each chemo after, I have to say was harder and harder as my hair had thinned so my scalp was more and more exposed... The headaches were about the same though in intensity and duration for chemo 2-6. BUT... I'm glad I kept going, my hair is thick and curly now, the thin patches filled in within weeks and I could go without a hat whilst having radiotherapy and it just looked like i had a bad cut with bits sticking up all over the place lol Icelollies make me feel nauseous even now and I wont be wearing a hat in a hurry this autumn, but yes am still glad I did it for my son and for me... Just realised my first chemo was a year ago today! wow that has flown by! Might be worth seeing if you could try one on and see what it feels like in terms of the pressure from the chin strap etc? Anywho, good luck with whatever you decide, even if you just manage the one at least you had a go! all the best, Nix x
Posts.Title: Migraine ladies

Posts.Content: Hi Jane, Tenderness I think is very common. I had a mx and node clearance last August and then started chemo in sept. I play netball and carried on playing throughout (only on my third week after chemo when I felt better), then I started to play every week when radiotherapy started. I wore a tight sports bra with my softie and found that it ached a bit after especially the node scar, now six months later I still get the odd pulling sensation and ache but find that the day after training it feels fab as has loosened the area and made it much more comfortable. I will say during and just after radio it was more tender than normal, but is very understandable as there has been so much trauma to the area. I take ibuprofen if it gets too sore but most of the time it's fine and after a couple of months I even forgot sometimes which was amazing    If you're worried I'd give you're bc nurse a ring as she can probably give you any advice you need, Nix x
Posts.Title: Exercising after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Suzy Jane, I haven't had an LD flap op, but have a temporary expander in (left side), and you're right when you first see it after the op its such a let down, mine looked like a deflated rugby ball until i had my "top ups"  now the swellings gone down, it's ok but not breast shaped and definitely doesn't match my other one. A friend of mine has had an ld flap and it looks amazing (she had it 5 years ago didn't see at the time but she said took a while to settle). Are they planning any more ops to shape/augment them? The loaf under your arm should settle down but it does take time. I'm not surprised you're still tired it is a big op, the psychological impact is as great as the physical. I hope it all settles down for you soon and that you have lots of help and support. Like JJ I'm planning to have a bilateral mx and diep recon next year...  it's not going to be perfect, they won't look the same as before but will hopefully end up with a pair of boobs I can live with. I walked into theatre for my sentinel node op and my mx. Was asked if I wanted to go down in the bed or walk, I felt more in control walking, iyswim. I agree if you're not happy you should tell someone. Your BC nurse or consultant maybe? As Misty said keep doing the exercises they really do help, take care, xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had bilateral masectomy with immediate LD flap reconstruction...

Posts.Content: Haven't read Lizz, but imagine it's complete tosh... Chemo is hard, but doable for most.... 5 months after the last one and it's a hazy memory for me. Like childbirth awful at the time but as each day passes a blur. I cold capped, was horrendous for me as I get headaches and these ones were intense... But it worked, I lost about 50% of hair mass, had the odd thin spot but my hair now is thick and looks healthy so am pleased I persevered. (May never eat an ice lolly again though!)  Week one of each chemo is tough, I lived in a fog for 7 days but by day 10 I started to feel ok, food tastes naff for a while, sweet and salty foods tasted best. The fog lasted longer as the sessions went on so by the 5/6 one it was 10 days not 7.  My 5th chemo was the 12th December and I still had a good Xmas, could taste and enjoy food I had a glass of prosecco which was recommended by the chemo nurses!  My advice, eat what you want, sleep when you need to and don't be afraid to ask for help Good luck hope all goes well for you Nix xx
Posts.Title: Decca Aitkenhead in the Guardian

Posts.Content: Hi,  Ha! I find it funny how we are all going through something so enormous yet hair growth is a top priority lol. I'm the same, I cold capped, so kept about 50% of my hair, had thinning on top and on the left side, scalp was clearly visible in these areas. I finished chemo the 5th January and have been going without a hat for about 3 weeks now, I dyed it before I did as the greyness made it appear thinner. I can't believe how quickly mine had thickened up, the top is a bit 'tufty' only the left side feels thinner. I have curly hair anyways and it's regrowing at odd angles.  I hate it as have it cut short but it's there, I don't look like an ill person anymore...  Btw I'm on tamoxifen, so am anticipating that it won't be as thick as before, but it's getting there!  Xx
Posts.Title: Question about hair growth

Posts.Content: Hi Val, Good luck with radio today, i didn't find it too bad, and actually quite relaxing at times with the hum of the machine lulling me! I had a lh mx so had to do the breathing thing .. so challenged myself every day to try and do it better and better each time (am a secret perfectionist lol) . Keep using the cream, I used Moo Goo udder cream which was fab.. Four weeks will fly by, treat yourself if you can each week  a nice coffee and cake or something you like.. I feel your pain with hair, i cold capped but when having radio (Feb this year) my hair was really thin on top and patches on the sides so was wearing wooly hats everywhere... six months on and i's wild now, have curls galore! I wear bandanas all the time as it hides the shorter patches and tames the long ones quite like the look but can wait for it to get a bit longer,  Take care, nearly there! big hugs, Nix xx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy. Hair is growing

Posts.Content: Hi Lou,  I also hope you get sorted, does sound odd though.  I've had mine filled 3 times since surgery and had one of them last week in week 2 of my first chemo. Has the consultant said what he's going to do? .. can it be moved without surgery?
Posts.Title: breast expander has moved

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, am also considering a delayed bilateral diep hopefully September this year.. Have just finished 15 rads after 6 X fec  so was told six months minimum before surgery. Am also getting slightly cold feet too... The more I think about it the op the more anxious I become, have heard wonderful things but am interested to see if anyone responds also X
Posts.Title: Delayed reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, am also considering a delayed bilateral diep hopefully September this year.. Have just finished 15 rads after 6 X fec  so was told six months minimum before surgery. Am also getting slightly cold feet too... The more I think about it the op the more anxious I become, have heard wonderful things but am interested to see if anyone responds also X
Posts.Title: Delayed reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi London Lass,  Sorry you're stressed, I'm 13 months post surgery (mx) and only 7 months post chemo and radio so in terns of changes they're happening all the time still. Personally i'd see your surgeon. If you wait to see the oncologist they'll only refer you to the surgeon so you may as well see them first. Imagine it's just the scar tissue I find after strenuous exercise it becomes more prominent and achy. I think the bcn is just being cautious (which is good really and ironically reassuring!) That little voice is your friend, (mine's saved me many times lol)  big hugs, Nix x
Posts.Title: Breast Changes 3 years on!!

Posts.Content: Hi London Lass,  Sorry you're stressed, I'm 13 months post surgery (mx) and only 7 months post chemo and radio so in terns of changes they're happening all the time still. Personally i'd see your surgeon. If you wait to see the oncologist they'll only refer you to the surgeon so you may as well see them first. Imagine it's just the scar tissue I find after strenuous exercise it becomes more prominent and achy. I think the bcn is just being cautious (which is good really and ironically reassuring!) That little voice is your friend, (mine's saved me many times lol)  big hugs, Nix x
Posts.Title: Breast Changes 3 years on!!

Posts.Content: Hi Ejm1 - I had Pagets too, haven't read or heard many people who've had it too, was diagnosed last May.  Looking back I had the classic symptoms too, itchy eczema which when I used cream would look better but wouldn't go away, but as I get itchy skin anyway didn't think anything of it, was intensely itchy at times too, wish now I'd known more about it as would prolly have gone and been checked out.  I had 2 other tumours in same breast, they thought originally one was tubular, but both were idc. The Pagets was found after my mx. I had no lumps visible, mine were picked up on my annual mammogram and MRI so was told not to kick myself that I hadn't felt anything.  Am waiting to have a bilateral mx and diep recon - are you happy with yours? I keep worrying about it as know the recovery's long?  Nix X
Posts.Title: Results of surgery

Posts.Content: Thanks for the reply Ellen, very helpful, am looking at the abdominal surgery like c section (had 2!) the recovery was painful, but you get there in the end. I have an expander implant at the mo which is really uncomfortable so am looking forward to having something more natural. Can't wait to lose the other boob as worry about it in the back of my mind....  Am waiting for my appointment with the ps, I saw him after diagnoses and he was fab, told me to do sit ups showed me amazing pics, unfortunately as had one node with cx I was recommended to have radio, which I did, but that meant delayed recon...  I play netball so didn't want an ld flap hopefully can get back to it after   Thanks also for the offer, when I know for sure what I'm doing I'll take you up on the offer for a pic, Will look up some of the threads about diep op, (poor JJ's having a torrid time of it ) All the best, Nix xx
Posts.Title: Results of surgery

Posts.Content: Ha Lizz yep I  must look a right goon when I'm out and something makes me laugh as things seem extra funny now lol.  Had a scatter brain moment last week though... so chemo brain is still lingering... I put petrol in my diesel car.. Nearly killed it I have no recollection of putting unleaded in its a blur never happened before as have always repeated the mantra 'black pump for diesel' as  I pull up... Luckily my ancient car is still working   Was also peeved that the leg hair came back so quickly thought I'd get a longer reprieve! Luckily face hair is minimal thought I'd end up as the bearded lady as dark haired lol Nix x
Posts.Title: EYELASHES!

Posts.Content: Some days are worse than others Lizz but if you can laugh about it you're half way there! Food shopping is hell at the mo as completely forget stuff even when it's written down! My lovely car is fine, thanks, apparently if it had been a newer car I would have definitely killed it... X
Posts.Title: EYELASHES!

Posts.Content: That's fab news Lizzy,  I only lost my lower lashes and kept lots of hair as cold capped but everyday am happy to look in the mirror now and see me getting back what I lost, have been told I look younger than ever so yay! Since being diagnosed I've found the smallest victories and pleasures make me happy. I'm not afraid to sing loudly in the car, I'm not frightened to wear something a bit different than normal and I'm not afraid to tell people how I feel anymore, life is for living and enjoying everyday!  Keep smiling lovely xx
Posts.Title: EYELASHES!

Posts.Content: hi Debbie, only had mine out 3 weeks ago so early days for me, it's fairly lumpy I'd say about the size of the port so think there must be lots of scar tissue that gets left behind when the port's removed. Sorry can't reassure you, good that they are sending you for an MRI, fingers crossed for you xx
Posts.Title: portacath scar tissue or a recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi Gillian, Sorry you feel rotten, with me the rubbish feeling lasted about 7 days for fec 1-3 then fec 4-6 it was 10 days. I think I checked my temp morning and evening, or if I had a headache that wouldn't shift or felt extra rough then I'd take it before taking some paracetamol. It really does hit you for six especially the first one as you have nothing to Compare it to.  Try to take it easy try and drink lots of fluids and sleep when you feel like it. I didn't really feel that sick but was given emend so maybe that's why, also had neulastin injections to boost my white cells so luckily didn't get any infections.  It was a humid evening last night so maybe you were warm due to that?  Maybe check every 3 or 4 hours until you feel a bit better and if you have any doubts ring the hospital again. Take care, is horrid, I still remember the way I felt with a shudder but hopefully by next week you'll start to feel a bit more human again.. is lovely having a week of feeling ok it's like the sun coming out after a storm.. Big hugs, Nix xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a Portacath in their arm? The one under the skin?

Posts.Content: Hi Gillian, that's ok, I don't check on here every day so probably wouldn't have seen your reply earlier... so glad you're feeling a bit better, sleep is a good thing and fab you've managed to get some, I slept terribly due to the steroids I didn't take any vitamins, still don't as was warned off them by my oncologist.. but imagine each oncologist has different ideas about what to take or not take..  I did the injections but only coz I was home alone when I needed to have it, I had the one injection the day after chemo and had the worst aches, shoulders especially for some reason, hope you don't get too achy... imagine they'll work fine... I was OTT about hand washing and washing fruit and veg just in case, was like being pregnant again lol.  Take care and look after yourself, Nix xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a Portacath in their arm? The one under the skin?

Posts.Content: Hi Gillian, I had a portacath fitted under a general anaesthetic, have rubbish veins too.. it was straightforward, no problems with scar, was fantastic through treatment and meant I could play netball still when I felt up to it, was put off a the picc line as is outside of body, everything with the portacath is hidden away... had it taken out just after my radiotherapy finished. The scar is in a naff place I think, would be better a bit lower as vest tops  highlight it but am still glad I had it done as know I'd never have coped having the chemo through my veins normally. I didn't feel a thing other than when the needle went in to set it up each time.  Am rubbing bio oil in the scar now so hopefully it will fade away eventually, but if it doesn't it's not a big deal, is small fry compared to what we've all been through treatment wise, have plenty of other scars... Hope it went ok and good luck with the chemo and rest of your treatment,  Nix xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a Portacath in their arm? The one under the skin?

Posts.Content: Well done! I  went to one my gorgeous friend had this morning (6 years post bc) she raised over £1000, people really are fab. Does restore my faith in people x
Posts.Title: Done my coffee morning

Posts.Content: Hi Sparky, Poor you feeling so rough, you need to concentrate on getting better not worrying about cancer critters! I was told that the chemo generally continues to protect for a little while after you finish (am having a preventative rh mastectomy next month, finished chemo in January and at last check up voiced my concerns about having to wait so long for the second op, that's what my consultant told me probably a fob off but made me feel slightly better!) Just imagine how ill you'd be if you weren't well before your op....  it takes a lot out of you and you need to be 100% strong to recover :)  You're obviously still a bit low so try and boost your immune system, lots of vitamin rich foods, soups are fab for that, if you don't feel well enough to go out for some, have you a friend or relative that can get some for you? Maybe you need stronger antibiotics too? Keep chatting on here, having a moan is fab, but mostly take care of yourself and try not to worry too much ( I know easier said than done) Big hugs, Nix xx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy op delayed by chest infection

Posts.Content: Hi Charlotte,  Am not 100% sure but think that about 11 days after chemo is when you maybe need to be more careful. I don't think they go fully back to "normal" until you've finished treatment. I can't say I was particularly careful then, I just carried on, watching the foods I ate, washing hands regularly and trying to avoid people who were ill.  I had Neulasta injections the day after chemo so had a boost each time, luckily I didn't get ill through my chemo. Just look after yourself, keep taking your temperature, if your levels are too low it may delay the next round, but the blood test before treatment will check that. Good luck hope the rest of your treatment goes well  Nix x
Posts.Title: Blood Cell Count

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, I'm sure they won't think you're nuts at all, after everything we have to go through being unsure of having something that you feel could potentially hurt and scar more is understandable.  My radiotherapy experience is like many others, I had 15 in all, the worst bit was the travelling, but I too found it relaxing, lying in a dimmed room only the hum of the machines and the occasional voices of the radiographers. My advice is talk it through, I was told that it was my choice whether to have it as I had only one node involved, there was no evidence that it would benefit greatly but I wanted to throw everything at this and be able to say I'd done everything I could to try and stop it coming back.  Moisturising was the key for me I think, I burn in the sun, then go brown so was conscious of this, I used Moo Goo Udder cream, and also Aveeno. Aveeno in the morning and the moo goo at night. My skin did feel tight and tingly but not too red and it didn't blister or break. I finished radio 21st Feb but am still using the same routine.  I'd go to the planning session, see how it goes, ask loads of questions, then make your decision, Good luck Helen, hope the rest of your treatment goes well  Nix xx
Posts.Title: Really struggling

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, I had a left mx last August with a temporary tissue expander put in at the same time (am having recon later due to radiotherapy), (also had an ANC which was the most painful bit to be honest...) Waking from surgery I had intense pain in the centre of my chest and think this was what woke me from the anaesthetic. I asked for some pain relief which I was given and thankfully worked, was told it was where the muscle goes over the implant it's a particularly sensitive area, after that was just a bit achy really, nothing major, the drain is a PITA as you prolly know... It does take some getting use to when lying down as feels odd it almost digs in, I still can't sleep in certain positions but it does get easier...  Am also having a mx with immediate recon on the right side but later this year due to having radiotherapy, when the temporary expander will be replaced with an implant ....  Good luck with the surgery hope all goes well for you Nix x
Posts.Title: Prophylactic mastectomy with tissue expander and implants... Advice...

Posts.Content: Hi Cassa, sorry haven't been a round for a bit  so just spotted your post ... yep I had Paget's disease, but didn't realise till post surgery when the histology results came back.. but as others have said I probably had the symptoms beforehand, really itchy nipple and areole and a dry patch actually on the nipple that wouldn't go away... I get very dry skin patches generally so didn't really think much of it.... I was told it was probably related to the tumour that was near my nipple (I was greedy had 2 of the buggers!) so am glad I had a mx without sparing the nipple as it would have been a waste of time... they may biopsy the area to see if you have it.  I had an MRI guided biopsy on the tumour near my nipple which was a bit unpleasant but don't have experience of the Paget's tests... imagine though they need to take a sample of the area and run some tests, Hope it's not too bad for you, Take care & big hugs  Nix xx
Posts.Title: Padgets desease

Posts.Content: Hi Juliet, I had 6 sessions of fec 100, (I'm ER+ and PR+) and asked why not fec-t was told this regime was worked out based on my results and receptors, it was a kinder regime apparently! All of which didn't really answer my question, but I think a lot of thought goes into tailoring the regimes for us, I can't imagine they would forget that you are her+. Defo ask as always best to have it clear in your mind.  Good luck with the rest of your treatment, I finished my chemo the beginning of Jan and am beginning to finally feel more normal, look after yourself xx
Posts.Title: why fec and the not fec t ?
